byline.contributor: Mitch Smith reported from Columbus, and Sheryl Gay Stolberg from Washington.
byline.original: By MITCH SMITH and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

abstract: Ballot initiative to legalize marijuana for both medical and personal use would amend Ohio Constitution to give exclusive commercial growing rights to group of wealthy investors; has met with opposition from diverse camps, failed to gain endorsement from many marijuana advocacy groups, and prompted competing initiative that would block proposal based on anti-monopoly argument.
lead_paragraph: Even longtime marijuana advocates are conflicted over a legalization measure that would grant exclusive rights to growing it commercially to a group of wealthy investors.

headline.main: On Ballot, Ohio Grapples With Specter of Marijuana Monopoly
headline.print_headline: Ohio Marijuana Vote Raises Fears of a Monopoly

snippet: Even longtime marijuana advocates are conflicted over a legalization measure that would grant exclusive rights to growing it commercially to a group of wealthy investors.
